channel.title: School Exam Project Issue
channel.description:
Hi dere,
This is written in PHP, Html and Css just so you know. It's a web exam.
So basically im having an issue with solving this problem basically, I have to create a exam for my school.
The problem is that the exam has 40-50 questions, if a user was to do the exam would I need 40 rows in the user database to store what they selected? How would I do it? <3 Also, if a student was to dissconnect mid exam how would I be able to store the students answers so they can come back to where they left off.
Thanks - Frantix

NoSQL? NoBRAINS.

I bet you have NoDick then

item.title: School Exam Project Issue
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Why the aversion to databases? Truth be told, they’re probably one of the more important things that computer science has gifted modern society. Efficient storage and retrieval of data underpins a large part of society’s capacity to do ‘stuff’.

Read full topic

item.title: School Exam Project Issue
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“Frantix, post:10, topic:543646”][quote author=Pwnd link=topic=662528.msg4428951#msg4428951 date=1402272096]
Why not use JSON at that point?
[/quote]

I was thinking just that, basically after they finish the exam it goes into a text document and or a excel sheet. Would this be better then doing it through a database?[/quote]
…No?

Go with a schema similar to what Pwnd suggested and you will be fine.

Read full topic

item.title: School Exam Project Issue
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

If multiple table relationships are absolutely beyond you then you could go with a delimited answer string.
For example:

1:A|2:B|3:C|4:A|5:C

This solution sucks though.

Read full topic

item.title: School Exam Project Issue
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Does the data for the entire test matter? Or does only the result at the end matter? Because that’d be super easy.

Otherwise, I’d probably take up lothy’s solution of having an object (the user), has many answers.

user:
user_id
user_name

questions:
question_id
question_test

answers:
answer_id
answer_value
user_id // this will be the associated id
question_id // this will link up with the question asked

I’m pretty fucked right now, and skipped half the thread, but… that’d probably be my approach based on the initial post.

Read full topic

item.title: School Exam Project Issue
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

This is how I (personally) would accomplish this issue. If the results are going to be read by you or school administrators, here’s one option…

After all the information has been inputted, on the process page you build a long paragraph containing all the answers.

An example of this would be a database structure like this…
id - information
1 - First Name: JohnLast Name: DoeQuestion 1: Yes

Etc. So when you’re later pulling the information, you can just select the one column as a whole and output it. This wouldn’t be ideal if you want to access the answers individually or pull the answers.

Another option would be building an array from the database, which isn’t really recommended. An example:
id - results
john, doe, yes […]

Then use PHP to separate values.

Without knowing whether or not the questions are just yes/no, involve multiple options, or include text, I wouldn’t be able to provide much support.

Read full topic

item.title: School Exam Project Issue
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Why don’t you want to have 50 rows per student? There are plenty of databases in the world that have billions of rows.
That’s the proper way to do it.

In any case, I’ve already given you all of the literature and tooling that you need to do the design side of things so you’re on your own now.

Read full topic

item.title: School Exam Project Issue
item.dc:creator: @Frantix Frantix
item.description:
@Frantix wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:2, topic:543646”]The solution to this can range from extremely simple (i.e., a two table solution that maps a student to zero-to-many answers) to comparatively complex (i.e., a larger database solution with tables that allow many students to sit many exams, with each question being defined in the database, each answer for those questions, etc).

Look up ER (entity relationship) diagrams on wikipedia and start thinking about the entities that you would need for your solution. Do yourself a favour and use crow’s foot notation - Chen notation takes up too much space.

And when you’ve done that, look into the concept of normal form. Brotip: nine in ten databases used in production software (i.e., real software with real users) will generally only go as high as 3NF. So if you aren’t overly interested in the university-level academic side of things yet then you can stop reading at 3NF.

Oh, and if you want a diagramming tool that’s free then I suggest yED (found here: http://www.yworks.com/en/products_yed_about.html).[/quote]

Mind fucked aha, the thing is is that it’s just a simple exam for students to sit and get there results at the end. I just need a way to store there answers in a database without having 50 lines in the database. Also I should have put above that it’s programmed in PHP. :S But thanks that was really technical for something so simple.

Read full topic

item.title: School Exam Project Issue
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

The solution to this can range from extremely simple (i.e., a two table solution that maps a student to zero-to-many answers) to comparatively complex (i.e., a larger database solution with tables that allow many students to sit many exams, with each question being defined in the database, each answer for those questions, etc).

Look up ER (entity relationship) diagrams on wikipedia and start thinking about the entities that you would need for your solution. Do yourself a favour and use crow’s foot notation - Chen notation takes up too much space.

And when you’ve done that, look into the concept of normal form. Brotip: nine in ten databases used in production software (i.e., real software with real users) will generally only go as high as 3NF. So if you aren’t overly interested in the university-level academic side of things yet then you can stop reading at 3NF.

Oh, and if you want a diagramming tool that’s free then I suggest yED (found here: http://www.yworks.com/en/products_yed_about.html).

Read full topic
